column2: VARIABLE TITLE WORKSHOP IN CURRICULUM AND INSTRUCTION
column6: Variable topic workshop designed to respond to curriculum trends and issues, and specialized needs.

column2: SPECIAL TOPICS IN CURRICULUM AND INSTRUCTION 1.000 TO 5.000
INDIVIDUAL INVESTIGATION IN CURRICULUM AND INSTRUCTION 1.000 TO 5.000
SPECIAL TOPICS IN CURRICULUM AND INSTRUCTION
column6: Student teaching.

Understanding of literacy learning in adolescence and adulthood (ages 12-21) with an emphasis on strategies for text learning, literacy in electronic environments and teaching students who struggle as readers and writers.

column2: TEACHING MATHEMATICS IN EARLY AND MIDDLE GRADES
column4: Advanced standing, minimum C (2.0) in MATH 14001 or 14002.
column6: Addresses pedagogical content knowledge for the teaching and learning of mathematics in grades K-9, based on the national content and process standards.

column2: SCIENCE TEACHING IN EARLY AND MIDDLE GRADES
column6: Addresses pedagogical content knowledge for the teaching and learning of science in grades K-9. In addition students examine how to best align science practice to state and national standards.

column2: TEACHING SOCIAL STUDIES IN EARLY AND MIDDLE GRADES
column6: Addresses pedagogical content knowledge for the teaching and learning of social studies in grades k-9,based on the national content and process standards.

column2: TEACHING READING AND WRITING IN MIDDLE GRADES
column6: Addresses pedagogical content knowledge for the teaching and learning of reading and writing in grades 4-9, based on the national content and process standards.

column2: VARIABLE TITLE WORKSHOP IN CURRICULUM AND INSTRUCTION
column6: Variable topic workshop designed to respond to curriculum trends and issues, and specialized needs.

column2: SPECIAL TOPICS: SEMINAR/WORKSHOP IN CURRICULUM AND INSTRUCTION
column6: Special topic: seminar workshop for international baccalaureate program,

column2: VARIABLE TITLE WORKSHOP IN EXERCISE, LEISURE AND SPORT
column6: Workshop in exercise, leisure and sport studies topics vary. Repeated registration permitted. Maximum 4 hours may be applied to degree.
Factors affecting athletic performance emphasizing skill, motivation, personality and practice conditions.
A focus on the philosophy, skills, strategies and tactics of coaching within contemporary society.

Approaches to teaching in elementary school physical education. Focusing on sequential curriculum development and on learning outcomes in three domains. Students are required to complete Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Identification (BCII) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) background checks and submit the results to authorized personnel at their assigned „school/agency‟ before the first day of the semester in which student teaching/ internship will take place.

Physical education content for the elementary school child with emphasis on developmentally appropriate learning in three domains. Students are required to complete Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Identification (BCII) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) background checks and submit the results to authorized personnel at their assigned Department/agency before the first day of the semester in which student teaching/ internship will take place.

Approaches to teaching in secondary school physical education. Focus on sequential curriculum development and on learning outcomes in three domains. Students are required to complete Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Identification (BCII) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) background checks and submit the results to authorized personnel at their assigned Department/agency before the first day of the semester in which student teaching/ internship will take place.

Introduction and development of content, management and organizational skills related to sports and activities utilized in secondary school physical education. Students are required to complete Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Identification (BCII) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) background checks and submit the results to authorized personnel at their assigned Department/agency before the first day of the semester in which student teaching/ internship will take place.

Understanding of literacy learning in adolescence and adulthood (ages 12-21) with an emphasis on strategies for text learning, literacy in electronic environments, and teaching students who struggle as readers and writers.

column2: TEACHING MATHEMATICS IN EARLY AND MIDDLE GRADES
column6: This course addresses pedagogical content knowledge for the teaching and learning of mathematics in grades K-9, based on the national content and process standards.

column2: SCIENCE TEACHING IN EARLY AND MIDDLE GRADES
column6: This course addresses pedagogical content knowledge for the teaching and learning of science in grades K-9. In addition students will examine how to best align science practice to state and national standards.

column2: TEACHING SOCIAL STUDIES IN EARLY AND MIDDLE GRADES
column6: This course addresses pedagogical content knowledge for the teaching and learning of social studies in grades K-9, based on the national content and process standards.

column2: TEACHING READING AND WRITING IN MIDDLE GRADES
column6: Addresses pedagogical content knowledge for the teaching and learning of reading and writing in grades K-9, based on the national content and process standards.
Thesis students must register for a total of 6 hours, 2 to 6 hours in a single semester distributed over several semesters if desired.
Thesis students must continue registration each semester until all degree requirements are met.

column2: ISSUES AND TRENDS IN SOCIAL STUDIES EDUCATION
column6: This course will provide an overview of historical trends and contemporary issues in social studies education.

column2: RESEARCH IN SOCIAL STUDIES TEACHING AND LEARNING
column6: During this course students will examine, discuss and study research in the teaching and learning of social studies as well as develop their own study of social studies teaching and learning.

Course provides experiences with and study of various uses of technology in social studies teaching and learning. During the course we will examine implications and effects of technology on student learning, teaching and society as a whole.
Teachers will be provided with knowledge and strategies for teaching children to function effectively in a pluralistic society.

column2: ISSUES AND TRENDS IN ELEMENTARY SCIENCE
column6: New discoveries in science, including issues in society with direct science content. Emphasis is on practical and simple classroom applications.
Course in issues relating to research methods pertinent to science education.

column2: CULTURE AND MULTICULTURALISM IN SCIENCE EDUCATION
column6: This course provides a general introduction to the impacts of multiculturalism and the social studies of science on science education. Implications for science educational curriculum theory, classroom practice and research are explored. Topics examined include, race and gender in science education, teaching the culture of science and teaching science in a global context.

column2: NATURE OF SCIENCE IN SCIENCE EDUCATION
column6: Course in issues relating to the nature of science as it impacts science education.

column2: HISTORY AND INQUIRY IN SCIENCE EDUCATION
column6: This course will investigate the continuing debate for what counts as science and how that vision has been represented throughout history. The impacts of the political, economic and societal factors on the nature of scientific inquiry will also be discussed within a historical context.

column2: VARIABLE TITLE WORKSHOP IN EXERCISE, LEISURE AND SPORT
column6: Workshop in exercise, leisure and sport topics vary. Repeated registration permitted. Maximum 4 hours applied to the degree.
Examination of contemporary motor learning and control theories and laboratory experiences, with emphasis upon motor skill acquisition and performance as studied experimentally. Laboratory included.
A course designed to enhance ability to develop more effective teaching/learning environments through the use of systematic observation and application of supervisory theory.

column2: PEDAGOGICAL ANALYSIS OF PHYSICAL EDUCATION AND SPORT
column6: An analysis of contemporary pedagogical models, practices and theories relevant to the multidimensional environments of physical education and sport.
The analysis, development and design of curricular theory and practice in physical education and sport. An examination of current and future issues in curriculum implementation.

A sixteen week practicum, in K-12 physical education, combining full-time student teaching and student teaching seminar. Eight weeks student teaching at the pre- department to fifth grade level and eight weeks at the sixth to twelfth grade level. Students are required to complete Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Identification (BCII) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) background checks and submit the results to authorized personnel at their assigned Department/agency before the first day of the semester in which student teaching/ internship will take place.

Supervised and supervisory experiences in motor development for all ages and abilities, including conceptual bases for assessment individualizations task analysis. Maximum of 6 hours applies to degree. Repeat registration permissible.

Supervised experience in organized sport focused upon the duties of a coach; can be at one or more levels (youth school college professional) and sports. A focus on the philosophy skills strategies and tactics of coaching within contemporary society. Students are required to complete Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Identification (BCII) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) background checks and submit the results to authorized personnel at their assigned Department/agency before the first day of the semester in which student teaching/ internship will take place.
Orientation to the curriculum field. Theoretical examination of foundations, elements, design and development of Department, college and non-department curricula.

This course explores the theories and practices of curriculum leadership with reference to the current politics of education and the democratic ideals of information-age, pluralistic societies. Mandated accountability reform is critically compared to invited professional renewal.
This course is designed to provide a broad overview of teacher education, including curriculum, organization, governance and policy.
This course is designed to provide a broad overview and conceptual framework for professional development; its historical, cultural, psychological and social contexts.

column2: INTERCULTURAL DIMENSIONS OF TEACHING AND LEARNING
column6: Increasing intercultural interaction in Departments and communities across the nation and around the world are prompting educational changes in terms of what is being taught and how it is being taught. Educators at all levels are increasingly being called upon to enhance their own intercultural competence and to consider how best to translate this to students in their charge. Addresses teaching and learning in the intercultural K-16 context.

column2: CRITICAL REFLECTION IN CURRICULUM AND INSTRUCTION
column6: Capstone course for a master‟s degree in curriculum and instruction. Students critique their content area studies with reference to the standard of curriculum-based pedagogy. Three concepts inform this critique: continuing professional development, multicultural education, curriculum leadership for reform and renewal.

Students will focus on designing program evaluation related to assessment, development and implementation of curricula, critique national and local curricular programs, apply elements of evaluation models.

column4: Instructor's special approval and graduate standing.
column6: A wide range of topics for advanced graduate inquiry. Normally a balance of theoretical study and creative application.

column2: ADVANCED PRACTICUM AND INTERNSHIP IN CURRICULUM AND INSTRUCTION
column6: Advanced practicum in curriculum and instruction. Students are required to complete Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Identification (BCII) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) background checks and submit the results to authorized personnel at their assigned „school/agency‟ before the first day of the semester in which student teaching/ internship will take place.

column2: INDIVIDUAL INVESTIGATION IN CURRICULUM AND INSTRUCTION
column6: Directed independent reading and/or research of special interest or need in student's program. Planned with and directed by a graduate faculty member.
Students pursue an individualized research project on a specialized topic with approval and under direction of instructor.
Emphasizes motivation, varied materials and methods, individual needs and sources of teacher help. Class members define goals and means.

column2: CURRICULUM AND ORGANIZATION IN THE MIDDLE GRADES
column6: History, philosophy, curriculum and organization of Departments serving children ages 8- 15. Emphasis on development of programs and curriculum that are responsive to the needs of early adolescents.

column2: SPECIAL TOPICS IN CURRICULUM AND INSTRUCTION
column6: Specialized offerings in response to emerging or selected program needs in curriculum design, development and CI 67108 TEACHING AND LEARNING IN THE MIDDLE GRADES Pedagogical theories and practices; approaches to instruction, relationship of teaching to learning and development for children ages 8 15.

column2: TEACHING MATHEMATICS USING COMPUTERS AND CALCULATORS
column6: The purpose is to develop knowledge of research and theories regarding teaching and learning mathematics via computing devices. Further to develop proficiency in the use of computing devices and software that would be used in the teaching and learning of mathematics.
Current research theory, methodology and results in mathematics education will be investigated. Implications for instructional practice and curriculum design will be examined.

column2: IMPROVING MATHEMATICS INSTRUCTION IN MIDDLE CHILDHOOD
column6: Instructional psychology and materials including technology for the effective teaching of mathematics in grade three through eight with a theoretical emphasis on cognitive development.

column4: Completion of 2 of the following: ADED 52267, CI 67224, CI 67226 or ECED 50147. Graduate standing.
column6: Investigation of standards and practices in mathematical assessments as recommended by NCTM and current research.

column4: Completion of 2 of the following: ADED 52267, CI 67224, CI 67226 or ECED 50147. Graduate standing.
column6: Investigation of alternative methods of teaching mathematics to diverse learners who experience difficulties in learning mathematics.

Survey course emphasizes current debates in environmental issues, exploring the interconnectedness of ecology, understanding the impact of culture and education on notions of environmental concerns, and how these ideas can be investigated within classroom contexts. The course is designed for teachers, science educators and other concerned citizens of the earth.

column4: Completion of 2 of the following: ADED 52267, CI 67224, CI 67226 or ECED 50147. Graduate standing.
column6: Experience in designing and administering both formal and informal assessments.

column2: THEORY AND PRACTICE IN THE TEACHING OF READING
column6: Nature and development of reading, approaches to instruction, relation to learning and development.
Issues and trends in instruction in listening and in oral and written expression.
Emphasizes a process approach to writing instruction in grades K through 12. Examines the steps and studies of composing, evaluation and components of a school wide program.
Presents a survey of selected types of literature appropriate for students in middle Department, junior high and high Department. Emphasis on evaluating, selecting and teaching.
Wide reading in children's literature, with particular application to school curriculum and field of reading.
A critical study of outstanding children's literature from early times to present.
Presents an in-depth survey of selected types of drama appropriate for elementary and middle school children. Theory and practice are emphasized.

Theory and application of diagnostic principles and remedial reading approaches with Department-age children. Cultural, linguistic, cognitive and affective factors in diagnosing and remediating reading problems.

column4: EVAL 65510 or EVAL 65511 or CI 67351 and graduate standing.
column6: Capstone experience in master's program in literacy in which students pursue an individualized literacy research program.
Application of previous courses includes supervised diagnostic/prescriptive reading work with Department-age pupils and diagnostic/remedial reporting.
Information and competencies for improving students' reading and studying in the content areas. Focus on intermediate grades through postsecondary years.
Emphasizes developmental nature of literacy learning in pre-department and primary grades; provides techniques for establishing effective reading and writing programs for young children.

This graduate level course is designed to support inquiry into literacy and its implications for women from the African diaspora. Several aspects of literacy will be considered i.e. verbal, visual and graphic. Questions will be raised about the implications of these forms of literacy for black women in different geographical locations.

column2: THEORY AND PRACTICE OF TEACHING LITERATURE-SECONDARY AND COLLEGE
column6: This course provides a rationale for and means of relating literary theory to classroom practice and pedagogical research. For secondary and post secondary English teachers.
Current theory and practices for teaching linguistically diverse writers at the secondary and post-secondary levels. Foundations for teaching language in the context of writing.
Exploration of issues in writing assessment, theoretical base for effective formative response to student writing and design, and implementation of writing assessment measures.

column2: ORGANIZATION AND SUPERVISION OF READING PROGRAMS
column6: Background and strategies for organizing and supervising reading programs. Emphasis on the state of the field roles and responsibilities and current issues.
Reading strategies for teachers of adult learners with emphasis on the role of the teacher and the development of programs.

column4: Reading specialization (READ) major and graduate standing.
column6: Inquiry into basic concepts and agendas for research through a study of historical, landmark and ground-breaking studies in literacy.

column4: CI 67310 or 77310; and 67319 or 77319; and 67323 or 77323; and 67330 or 77330; and MCED 50005 and graduate standing.
column6: Focus on principles and strategies related to literacy coaching p--adult, within classrooms, Departments and districts.

column2: ADVANCED PRACTICUM AND INTERNSHIP IN READING
column6: Supervised program requiring application of theory and practices in reading in field settings. Planned with and directed by a graduate faculty member. Students are required to complete Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Identification (BCII) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) background checks and submit the results to authorized personnel at their assigned „school/agency‟ before the first day of the semester in which student teaching/ internship will take place.
Specialized offerings in response to emerging or selected program needs in reading.

column2: INDIVIDUAL INVESTIGATION IN READING AND LANGUAGE ARTS
column6: Directed independent reading and/or research of special interest or need in student's program. Planned with and directed by a graduate faculty member.

Developing technologies are changing the very definition of "literacy." Designed to provide an overview of current (and past) theory and practices related to the growing line of inquiry known as “new literacies” Participants of the class follow their own paths of inquiry related to the question: How is our definition of “literacy” changing? Participants engage in discussions of theoretical positions related to this question (from perspectives as “new literacies,” “multiliteracies,” and “arts-based knowing” to name a few) as well as encounter such "nuts and bolts" information as how to set up a blog or a wiki and basics of video editing. Appropriate for any educator who is interested in examining how “new literacies” are transforming our classrooms.

column4: Choose 2 of 4: ADED 52267, CI 67224 and 67226, ECED 50147. Graduate standing.
column6: Practicum in Math Intervention.
An in-depth exploration of the theoretical frameworks and methodologies used in current research in mathematics education will be conducted.

column4: ADED 52267, CI 67224 and 67226, ECED 50147. Doctoral standing.
column6: Practicum in Math Intervention.
An in-depth exploration of the theoretical frameworks and methodologies used in current research in mathematics education will be conducted.

Beginning doctoral seminar. Students begin to explore the field of curriculum and instruction by reading and discussing foundational and current theories and research in the field. Students will begin to identify and explore their research interests in the field.

Advanced doctoral seminar. This will be a structured opportunity for students to synthesize research from the field, explore research options for their dissertation study, review literature for their research studies and discuss the development of their research.

Doctoral dissertation for which registration in at least two semesters is required, first of which will be semester in which dissertation work is begun and continuing until the completion of 30 hours.
Continuing registration required of doctoral students who have completed the initial 30 hours of dissertation and continuing until all degree requirements are met.

Focuses on critical study of contrasting approaches to the study of teaching processes. Surveys issues to give students a more critical perspective and to provoke thought about the relationship among theory research and practice. Required of Curriculum and Instruction Ph.D. students.

Focuses on historic and contemporary examples of curriculum theory and their application in curriculum design, development and evaluation. Examines modes of inquiry used by curriculum researchers and contemporary curriculum issues. Required of CI Ph.D students.

column2: FORMS OF INQUIRY IN CURRICULUM AND INSTRUCTION
column6: Introduction to the history, context, philosophy and ethics of inquiry in curriculum and instruction. Emphasis on acquainting Curriculum and Instruction doctoral students with faculty lines of inquiry and research foci while preparing doctoral students for critical consumption of and significant contribution to inquiry in curriculum and instruction.

column4: Doctoral standing and instructor's special approval.
column6: A wide range of topics for advanced graduate inquiry. Normally a balance of theoretical study and creative application.
Students pursue an individualized research project on a specialized topic with approval and under direction of instructor.
An introduction to a perspective on psychological processes underlying levels of reading from pre-reading to mature reading with implications for instruction.

Exploration of some of the issues, methods and findings on the relationship of reading and language. Examination of selected issues such as dialect bilingualism readability language based-strategies for reading instruction.
Issues and methodologies in research in the teaching of writing. Students will review the literature and conduct research in a significant area of writing instruction.
Variable topic seminar for advanced study of specialized areas and topics. Normally designed around research and theory applied to practice.

column2: RESEARCH IN READING AND LANGUAGE ARTS
column6: Students pursue an individualized research project on a specialized topic with approval and under direction of instructor.

Participants engage in discussions of theoretical positions related to this question (from perspectives as “new literacies,” “multiliteracies,” and “arts-based knowing” to name a few) as well as encounter such "nuts and bolts" information as how to set up a blog or a wiki and basics of video editing. Appropriate for any educator who is interested in examining how “new literacies” are transforming our classrooms.

column4: Doctoral standing and CI major and special approval from instructor.
column6: Doctoral Seminar in Math Education.
